fields.description:
During the verification of EUCA-11428, I found that there are scalability issues when many CF stacks are created in multi-UFS hosts. The same workload when run on a single UFS finishes in 40 minutes, but on the scale setup with 5 UFS hosts it is stuck in one of IN_PROGRESS status after 16 hours. Following is the comment on the ticket. 

 I ran the same bucket-creating CF template and created 2000 stacks. In the beginning, I saw about 300 stacks failing (due to timeout) per hour. Then about 16 hours later this morning, about 1000 stacks are stuck in CREATE_IN_PROGRESS (and 300 in ROLLBACK_IN_PROGRESS). Before running the benchmark, I've doubled the thread count in the property. There are 5 UFS in this scale setup. Is this behavior expected?
root@a-02-l ~# euctl cloudformation.swf_activity_worker_config
cloudformation.swf_activity_worker_config =
{"PollThreadCount": 16, "TaskExecutorThreadPoolSize": 32, "MaximumPollRateIntervalMilliseconds": 50 }
root@a-02-l ~# euctl cloudformation.swf_workflow_worker_config --format raw --dump
{ "MaximumPollRateIntervalMilliseconds": 50, "DomainRetentionPeriodInDays": 1, "PollThreadCount": 32 }

from [~sjones] running with 5 hosts and then also doubling the pollers would likely result in the need to change other configuration settings such as the number of transaction retries after failed updates. When monitoring workflows fail then you can see stacks stuck in particular states.

So two issues to address are:
1) Make sure the default setting is good for multi-UFS setup
2) Scale-related parameters should be more straightforward and not dependent on the particular topology. 

These issues may be addressed when SWF improvements are made in 5.0.
fields.summary: CloudFormation has scalability issue with multiple UFS

comments.body: Another issue related to increasing the PollThreadCount settings is that the current long polling implementation ties up threads. With the default settings 16 threads are used, but for the test this was changed to 48 (out of 64), leaving few threads available for all other uses.
This may be addressed by changes in 4.4. We should evaluate and close if fixed, else move to 5.0 for further work.

[~sjones], 

I tested this by trying to create 2000 stacks on a cloud setup with 3 UFS.  I didn't change any of the cloud properties mentioned above.  Once completed (around 30 mins), the stack state results are as follows:
{code}
[root@a-34-l ~]# euform-describe-stacks --region eng-admin@ | grep STACK | awk '{print $3}' | sort | uniq -c
    139 CREATE_COMPLETE
   1901 ROLLBACK_COMPLETE
{code}
Is this expected due to the fix?

[~hspencer], without knowing what the stack consists of is it is hard to say if that is an expected result.

EDIT: looking at your #s perhaps you are creating buckets without having changed objectstorage.max_buckets_per_account from the default value of 100?
[~hspencer], could you see why the stacks are failing and rolling back? (stack events)

[~sjones],

I saw the following error for each failed stack:
{code}
EVENT   BucketStack1074 974c1d57-6220-499d-bee5-011cf4d0d2de    AWS::CloudFormation::Stack      BucketStack1074 arn:aws:cloudformation::000225068559:stack/BucketStack1074/d51e6e51-c149-4308-b146-0dc9e73abe74 2017-03-08T04:14:10.017Z        CREATE_FAILED   The following resource(s) failed to create: [S3Bucket].
EVENT   BucketStack1074 S3Bucket-CREATE_FAILED-1488946448767    AWS::S3::Bucket S3Bucket                2017-03-08T04:14:08.767Z        CREATE_FAILED   Status Code: 400, AWS Service: Amazon S3, AWS Request ID: fe4f9157-8224-417c-961e-62da7344c0f2, AWS Error Code: TooManyBuckets, AWS Error Message: Status Code: 400, AWS Service: Amazon S3, AWS Request ID: null, AWS Error Code: TooManyBuckets, AWS Error Message: null
{code}
I attached a file that lists all the {{CREATE_FAILED}} error messages from each stack - {{2000BucketStackCreationErrors.txt}}.

The cloud property for the number of buckets was set to 3000 prior to the test being executed.  I didn't see any other cloud property regarding buckets.  Is there some other cloud property(ies) I should be looking at?

[~hspencer], I think that is all you need to configure for the bucket limit, it takes a few seconds for the update to be picked up by ufs. Is there a pattern to the failures?, i.e. earlier stacks failed, later ones succeeded after the new limit was picked up. Might be worth testing with a new account if you did not already to so.

Hey [~sjones],

I looks like there is a pattern regarding the failure.  I set up another Eucalyptus cloud, and federated to the existing cloud.  In addition, I created another account ({{development-operations}}).  I used the same cloudformation template, and set the bucket limit to 3000 on both clouds:
{code}
[root@a-34-l ~]# euctl objectstorage.max_buckets_per_account
objectstorage.max_buckets_per_account = 3000

[root@d-11 ~]# euctl objectstorage.max_buckets_per_account
objectstorage.max_buckets_per_account = 3000
{code}
I tested both clouds with the new account:
{code}
[root@a-34-l ~]# for x in {1..2000}; do euform-create-stack BucketStack${x} --template-file cfn-bucket-template.json --region devops-admin@region-one; sleep 1; done
[root@a-34-l ~]# for x in {1..2000}; do euform-create-stack BucketStack${x} --template-file cfn-bucket-template.json --region devops-admin@region-two; sleep 1; done
{code}
The result on both regions are as follows:
{code}
[root@a-34-l ~]# euform-describe-stacks --region devops-admin@region-one | grep STACK | grep BucketStack | awk '{print $3}' | sort | uniq -c
    997 CREATE_COMPLETE
   1003 ROLLBACK_COMPLETE
[root@a-34-l ~]# euform-describe-stacks --region devops-admin@region-two | grep STACK | grep BucketStack | awk '{print $3}' | sort | uniq -c
    997 CREATE_COMPLETE
   1003 ROLLBACK_COMPLETE
{code}
The error was the same on both clouds (for example):
{code}
EVENT   BucketStack1175 S3Bucket-CREATE_FAILED-1489086367034    AWS::S3::Bucket S3Bucket                2017-03-09T19:06:07.034Z        CREATE_FAILED   Status Code: 400, AWS Service: Amazon S3, AWS Request ID: 5418096f-0728-4ad2-820b-94b602208050, AWS Error Code: TooManyBuckets, AWS Error Message: Status Code: 400, AWS Service: Amazon S3, AWS Request ID: null, AWS Error Code: TooManyBuckets, AWS Error Message: null
{code}
I attached the {{CREATE_FAILED}} events from the failed stacks for both clouds.
[^2000BucketStackCreationErrorsRegionOne.txt]  [^2000BucketStackCreationErrorsRegionTwo.txt]  
Information for the clouds is as follows:

* [hspencer-529-maint-4.4|http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Maint_4.4/529/]
* [hspencer-540-maint-4.4|http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Maint_4.4/540/] 

 Let me know if you need any additional information.
[~hspencer], you will need to make changes to the underlying s3 implementation if you are hitting limits there. It looks like cloudformation is working as expected.

[~sjones], you were correct.  The Ceph backend was set to 1000 buckets for that user.  I assumed that when we updated the cloud property, it updated the property for that user in Ceph.  Thanks for the bread crumbs. :-)
Moving 4.4.0 Issues from Release Pending to Resolved
